home.riaiDescription1: Riai represents the fundamental principle that unifies all aspects of Aikido training. It teaches that the movements of the body, sword, and staff share the same essential principles.
home.riaiDescription2: In Iwama style, developed by O-Sensei Morihei Ueshiba during his years in the rural town of Iwama, this integration is paramount. Training with weapons illuminates the principles of empty-hand techniques.
home.exploreFoundational: Explore the foundational techniques of Iwama Aikido
home.connectWithDojos: Connect with authentic Iwama Aikido dojos around the world
home.quote: Aikido is not a technique to fight with or defeat an enemy. It is the way to reconcile the world and make human beings one family.

kids.name: Kids (4 - 11 years old)
kids.goal: Fun, safe, building a foundation of discipline.
benefitDetails: Children learn to fall safely, protecting their head and joints when tripping at school or playing.
Through repetitious katas, children learn mind-body connection, reducing distraction.
The dojo environment requires bowing and respecting partners, helping children develop emotional intelligence.

teens.name: Teens (12 - 17 years old)
teens.goal: Self-defense skills, relieving study pressure, stress relief.
benefits: Learning to protect the body when falling
benefitDetails: Progressing through ranks and mastering techniques helps teenagers trust their own abilities.
High-energy classes build flexible muscles and noticeably increase physical stamina.
Falling skills (Ukemi) protect teens from serious injuries in other sports activities.
Dojo discipline teaches teenagers polite behavior and helps control impulsive adolescent emotions.

adults.name: Adults (18+)
adults.goal: Work-life balance, enduring physical training, and the philosophy of Aiki.
benefitDetails: The mindfulness (Zanshin) in Aikido brings your mind to the present, clearing anxiety.
An hour of sweaty practice is the perfect antidote to an 8-hour office desk routine.
Develop self-protection reflexes by neutralizing attacking force rather than matching strength with strength.

corePillars.title: The 3 Golden Pillars
corePillars.subtitle: The Dojo Guarantee
corePillars.guarantee: 100% non-violent training environment, using absolute safety standard mats.

pillar1.title: Non-violent Self-defense
pillar1.description: Resolve school conflicts without causing injury.

pillar2.title: Discipline & Respect
pillar2.description: Japanese dojo etiquette cultivates a healthy lifestyle.

pillar3.title: Fitness & Digital Detox
pillar3.description: An excellent way to step away from phones and TVs.

techniques.title: Technique Library
techniques.description: Explore the traditional techniques of Iwama style Aikido, including empty-hand techniques (Taijutsu), sword work (Aiki-Ken), and staff practices (Aiki-Jo).
techniques.adjustFilters: Try adjusting your filters to see more results.
techniques.syllabusDescription: Click on a technique to view details. Green indicates techniques required for the selected belt level.

dojos.title: Dojo Directory
dojos.description: Connect with authentic Iwama Aikido dojos around the world. Each dojo is dedicated to preserving and transmitting the traditional teachings of O-Sensei.
dojos.searchPlaceholder: Search by name, location, or instructor...
dojos.adjustSearch: Try adjusting your search to see more results.
dojos.journeyDescription: The path of Aikido begins with a single step. Contact a dojo near you to observe a class or begin your training in the traditional ways of Iwama style.
dojos.geolocationNotSupported: Geolocation is not supported by your browser

events.sectionSubtitle: Join us in training and celebration across our global dojo network
events.pageDescription: Discover upcoming seminars, gasshuku, workshops, and examinations at Iwama Aikido dojos worldwide
events.winterGasshuku2026Desc: Annual winter intensive training camp at the birthplace of Iwama Aikido. Three days of focused practice in taijutsu, aiki-ken, and aiki-jo under the guidance of Hitohira Saito Sensei.
events.weaponsSeminarFebDesc: A full-day seminar focusing on the integration of ken and jo with empty-hand techniques, exploring the principle of Riai.
events.springGasshuku2026Desc: Four-day spring training camp on the West Coast. Open to all levels. Experience the depth of Iwama style in an immersive training environment.
events.beginnerWorkshopMarDesc: An introductory workshop designed for newcomers to Aikido. Learn the fundamental principles and basic techniques in a supportive environment.
events.danExaminationAprDesc: Official dan examination at Honbu Dojo. Candidates must have recommendation from their instructor and meet the required training hours.
events.summerIntensive2026Desc: Ten-day intensive training program at Iwama Honbu Dojo. Daily practice of taijutsu, weapons, and meditation. Limited to experienced practitioners.

footer.description: Preserving and sharing the traditional teachings of Iwama style Aikido through the principle of Riai - the unity of body, sword, and staff.
footer.quote: True Budo is a work of love. It is a work of giving life to all beings, and not killing or struggling with each other.
footer.copyright: © {year} Iwama Aikido Digital Library. All rights reserved.

notFound.description: Like a student who has lost their way, this page cannot be found. Let us guide you back to the dojo.
notFound.proverb: Seven times down, eight times up.

bokken.title: 木剣 Bokken
bokken.subtitle: Wooden Sword
bokken.description: In Iwama Aikido, the wooden sword (Bokken) is the foundation for understanding the principle of Riai. O-Sensei believed that all empty-hand techniques originate from the sword. Training with Bokken helps develop:
points: Tegatana (Hand blade) - Using hands like a sword

jo.title: 杖 Jo
jo.subtitle: Wooden Staff
jo.description: The Jo staff in Iwama Aikido was developed by O-Sensei from ancient Sojutsu arts. The Jo has unique advantages in combat as it can strike from both ends and is flexible in confined spaces.
points: Two-end attacks - More flexible than sword
Safe distance - Keep opponent at bay
31 Jo Kata - Foundation kata created by O-Sensei

techniqueDetail.keyPosturesDesc: Master these fundamental positions to develop proper form and understanding
techniqueDetail.importantNotesDesc: Essential insights from masters to deepen your practice
techniqueDetail.characteristicsDesc: Unique qualities that define this technique

tai-no-henko.name: Body Change
tai-no-henko.description: Body turning technique - mandatory warm-up in every Iwama class to train harmony (ki) and hip (koshi).

kamae.title: Kamae
kamae.description: Stand in hanmi stance, facing partner. Keep center low and stable.

receive.title: Receive Grab
receive.description: Partner grabs your wrist. In Kihon, they grip firmly.

tenkan.title: Tenkan
tenkan.description: Turn 180 degrees, rear foot steps in an arc behind, leading partner in the turning direction.

notes: Keep center low throughout the turn.
Don't use arm strength, use hips to lead.
Ki no Nagare is performed when partner just touches, not waiting for firm grip.

morotedori-kokyuho.name: Two-Hand Grab Breath Power
morotedori-kokyuho.description: Breath power method when grabbed with two hands on one - exercise to throw using hip power and breath.

grabbed.title: Being Grabbed
grabbed.description: Partner uses both hands to firmly grab one of your wrists.

extend.title: Extension
extend.description: Using power from hips and hara (lower abdomen), extend arm upward or outward.

throw.title: Throw
throw.description: Continue extension to break partner's balance and throw them down.

notes: Coordinate breath: inhale to prepare, exhale to extend.
Don't use shoulder strength, power must come from hips.

ikkyo.name: First Teaching (Arm Pin)
ikkyo.description: Lock #1 (Ude Osae) - Elbow pinning technique, the most fundamental foundation in Aikido. Teaches the principle of controlling partner's center through arm manipulation.

kamae.title: Ai-hanmi Kamae
kamae.description: Begin in matching stance with partner. Maintain proper distance (ma-ai).

entry.title: Irimi Entry
entry.description: As partner attacks, blend by entering deeply alongside their arm. Front hand on elbow, rear hand guides wrist.

pin.title: Osae (Pin)
pin.description: Guide partner down to mat in spiral motion. Final pin: partner face-down, arm extended, elbow and shoulder locked.

notes: Never use force against force. Ikkyo works through proper timing and angle.
Keep your center connected to partner's center throughout the technique.
The cutting motion must originate from your hips, not your arms (tegatana).

nikyo.name: Second Teaching (Wrist Turn)
nikyo.description: Lock #2 (Kote Mawashi) - Inward wrist twist. Develops sensitivity to pressure and angle while maintaining connection.

grip.title: Wrist Grip
grip.description: After blending with attack, grip partner's wrist in C-grip. Thumb on back of hand, fingers wrapped around wrist.

rotate.title: Wrist Rotation
rotate.description: Rotate partner's wrist inward while controlling elbow. Rotation must be smooth and continuous.

pin.title: Kneeling Pin
pin.description: Bring partner down using wrist lock, transition to kneeling position. Final pin secures both wrist and elbow.

notes: Nikyo effectiveness comes from precise angle, not crushing force. Find the right angle and technique requires minimal effort.
Always maintain elbow control. Without elbow control, partner can escape the wrist lock.

sankyo.name: Third Teaching (Wrist Twist)
sankyo.description: Lock #3 (Kote Hineri) - Upward spiral wrist twist through entire arm to shoulder. Embodies the spiral nature of Aikido movement.

capture.title: Hand Capture
capture.description: Capture partner's hand with both hands, creating structure with fingers wrapped over their hand and thumbs pressing into palm.

spiral.title: Spiral Rotation
spiral.description: Rotate partner's hand in spiral motion toward their centerline. Elbow rises as rotation continues.

control.title: Standing Control
control.description: Maintain lock while transitioning to various positions. Sankyo can lead to throws or pins depending on situation.

notes: The spiral must be continuous and connected to your center movement.
Be careful not to over-rotate causing wrist injury. Apply lock smoothly and give partner time to tap.

yonkyo.name: Fourth Teaching (Wrist Press)
yonkyo.description: Lock #4 (Tekubi Osae) - Pressure point on wrist. Uses pressure on nerve inside forearm to control partner.

grip.title: Forearm Grip
grip.description: Grip partner's forearm with index finger knuckle pressing the pressure point on inside forearm.

pressure.title: Pressure Point
pressure.description: Apply pressure with knuckle while maintaining Ikkyo-style control on arm.

lead.title: Lead Down
lead.description: Use pressure point combined with arm control to lead partner down to mat.

notes: Pressure point is located about 1-2 inches from wrist on inside forearm.
Yonkyo requires much practice to find the right position. Not everyone is sensitive to this point.

gokyo.name: Fifth Teaching (Arm Stretch)
gokyo.description: Lock #5 (Ude Nobashi) - Similar to Ikkyo but with reverse grip to disarm knife. Specifically used for tanto-dori (knife taking).

defense.title: Knife Defense
defense.description: When partner attacks with knife, blend and grip their wrist with thumb facing down (opposite of Ikkyo).

control.title: Elbow Control
control.description: Keep partner's elbow extended and locked, preventing them from cutting you.

disarm.title: Disarm and Pin
disarm.description: Lead partner down while disarming knife from their hand.

notes: The reverse grip in Gokyo keeps knife blade pointing away from you.
Always keep partner's elbow extended so they cannot cut.

rokkyo.name: Sixth Teaching (Elbow Lock)
rokkyo.description: Lock #6 (Hiji Kime Osae) - Elbow joint lock. Advanced locking technique focused on immobilizing elbow.

grip.title: Arm Grip
grip.description: Grip partner's arm with one hand on wrist, other hand on elbow.

lock.title: Elbow Lock
lock.description: Press partner's elbow upward while keeping wrist low, creating pressure on elbow joint.

complete.title: Complete Lock
complete.description: Lead partner to mat with elbow locked.

notes: Be careful when applying as this technique can injure elbow if used too strongly.
Rokkyo is less common than other locks but very effective in certain situations.

shihonage.name: Four Directions Throw
shihonage.description: Four-direction throw - Iwama specialty: grip hand firmly like holding sword in front of chest. Throwing technique that can project partner in any of four cardinal directions.

grasp.title: Katate-dori Grasp
grasp.description: From same-side wrist grab, blend with partner's energy while securing their wrist with both hands.

pivot.title: Tenkan Pivot
pivot.description: Execute 180-degree pivot while raising partner's arm overhead. Your movement must be under partner's arm.

throw.title: Throw Completion
throw.description: Complete throw by cutting down with partner's arm while stepping through. Partner falls backward.

notes: Iwama specialty: hold hand like gripping sword in front of chest.
Pivot must bring you completely under partner's arm. Partial rotation results in weak or dangerous technique.
Throw comes from hip rotation, not pulling arm.

iriminage.name: Entering Throw
iriminage.description: Entering throw - Enter the 'dead zone' behind partner's neck. Technique embodies irimi principle - moving directly into and through attack.

entry.title: Initial Entry
entry.description: Enter deeply past partner's attack, positioning yourself alongside them with hip connected to their center.

spiral.title: Spiral Drawing
spiral.description: Draw partner's balance in circular motion, lowering their center while maintaining connection through arm and body.

throw.title: Final Throw
throw.description: Complete throw by entering again while arm guides partner's head and neck backward.

notes: True irimi requires complete commitment. Half-hearted entry leaves you vulnerable to counter-attack.
Throw should feel like a wave - partner is drawn in, then projected out.

kotegaeshi.name: Wrist Return Throw
kotegaeshi.description: Wrist reversal throw - Throwing technique by reversing partner's wrist, creating pressure on wrist joint and breaking balance.

grip.title: Wrist Grip
grip.description: Grip partner's wrist with one hand on back of hand, other hand supporting from below.

turn.title: Wrist Turn
turn.description: Turn partner's wrist outward and downward, toward them.

throw.title: Throw
throw.description: Continue turning motion to throw partner down. They must flip over to avoid wrist injury.

notes: Wrist turn must combine with tenkan to create momentum.
Don't just use hands, use entire body to create turning force.

kaitennage.name: Rotation Throw
kaitennage.description: Rotational throw - Two types: Uchi (under armpit) and Soto (outside neck). Characteristic rotational throwing technique.

lead.title: Grip and Lead
lead.description: Grip partner's arm and lead them in an arc.

rotate.title: Rotation
rotate.description: Uchi: Go under partner's armpit. Soto: Press from outside neck.

throw.title: Complete Throw
throw.description: Continue rotational movement to throw partner down in arc.

notes: Clearly distinguish Uchi and Soto to apply in correct situations.
Keep partner off-balance throughout rotational movement.

tenchinage.name: Heaven and Earth Throw
tenchinage.description: Heaven and earth throw - Technique by separating partner's two hands in opposite directions: heaven (up) and earth (down).

separate.title: Heaven-Earth Separation
separate.description: One hand reaches to heaven (ten), other hand points to earth (chi), creating separating force on partner.

throw.title: Enter and Throw
throw.description: Step in deeply while maintaining separation, break balance and throw partner.

notes: Both hands must move simultaneously and decisively.
Irimi step must be simultaneous with hand separation.

koshinage.name: Hip Throw
koshinage.description: Hip throw - Iwama has many Koshi-nage variations. Throwing technique using hip as main fulcrum.

entry.title: Deep Entry
entry.description: Enter deeply beside or in front of partner, placing your hip lower than their center of gravity.

lift.title: Lift onto Hip
lift.description: Use hip as fulcrum, lift partner up.

throw.title: Throw over Hip
throw.description: Rotate and lower to throw partner over your hip.

notes: Iwama has many different Koshi-nage variations depending on attack type.
Hip must be lower than partner's center of gravity to throw effectively.
Need good ukemi (breakfall) practice before training this technique.

jujinage.name: Cross Throw
jujinage.description: Cross throw (Juji Garami) - Cross partner's two arms into X-shape then throw.

grip.title: Grip Both Hands
grip.description: From ryote-dori or similar situation, control both of partner's wrists.

cross.title: Cross Arms
cross.description: Lead partner's two arms to cross each other into X-shape (十).

throw.title: Throw
throw.description: Use crossed structure to break balance and throw partner.

notes: Keep partner's two hands tightly crossed so they cannot escape.
Throw must come from body movement, not arm strength.

kokyunage.name: Breath Throw
kokyunage.description: Breath power throw - This is the broadest group of techniques, no fixed pattern, highly variable. Throwing using kokyu-ryoku (breath power).

receive.title: Receive Attack
receive.description: Blend with any type of attack from partner.

guide.title: Guide Energy
guide.description: Use kokyu (breath/energy) to guide partner's energy.

throw.title: Natural Throw
throw.description: Throw partner in direction their energy is going, no fixed locking technique needed.

notes: Kokyu-nage is the broadest technique group, including any throw not in other categories.
No fixed pattern - requires high sensitivity and flexibility.
Demonstrates advanced mastery when able to throw smoothly without using force.

kokyu-ho.name: Breath Power Exercise
kokyu-ho.description: Seated breath power exercise. Usually performed at end of each class to train kokyu-ryoku.

seiza.title: Seiza
seiza.description: Both partners sit in seiza facing each other. Partner firmly grabs both your wrists.

extend.title: Extension
extend.description: Extend arms forward and upward while keeping shoulders relaxed. Power comes from hara (lower abdomen).

project.title: Projection
project.description: Continue extension to break partner's balance and push them backward.

notes: Relax shoulders completely. Tension blocks power flow from center.
Breathe naturally throughout. Holding breath creates stiffness and weakness.

suburi-ichi.name: First Sword Swing
suburi-ichi.description: The first and most fundamental sword swing in Aiki-ken. This exercise develops proper cutting form, breath coordination, and center movement.

chudan.title: Chudan Kamae
chudan.description: Begin in middle guard position with sword tip at throat height. Grip relaxed but firm.

raise.title: Raise (Furikaburi)
raise.description: Raise sword overhead in large arc. Tip travels past your centerline.

cut.title: Cut (Kirioroshi)
cut.description: Execute downward cut by dropping center and letting gravity assist. Stop with tip at knee height.

notes: Cut must come from your center, not arms. Your body drops, sword follows.
Coordinate breath: inhale on raise, exhale on cut.

kumitachi-ichi.name: First Paired Sword
kumitachi-ichi.description: The first paired sword kata in Iwama Aiki-ken. Develops timing, distance, and ability to read opponent's intention.

opening.title: Opening Position
opening.description: Both partners begin in chudan kamae at proper distance (issoku itto no ma).

attack.title: Attack and Response
attack.description: Uchitachi initiates with shomen cut. Uketachi receives by raising sword and blending with incoming energy.

counter.title: Counter and Conclusion
counter.description: Uketachi completes kata with decisive counter-cut while uchitachi accepts technique.

notes: Uchitachi's role is to provide sincere attacks to develop uketachi's ability.
Kata should flow naturally once learned. Hesitation or rushing indicate areas for improvement.

jo-suburi-ichi.name: First Staff Swing
jo-suburi-ichi.description: First staff swing exercise. Jo practice in Iwama style develops circular movement, both-handed coordination, and flowing energy.

kamae.title: Choku-tsuki Kamae
kamae.description: Hold jo with both hands, rear hand near end, front hand about one-third from tip. Jo points at opponent's throat.

prepare.title: Thrust Preparation
prepare.description: Draw jo back along centerline while shifting weight to rear foot. Jo remains level.

thrust.title: Thrust Execution
thrust.description: Drive forward with rear foot while extending jo in straight thrust. Power comes from hips.

notes: Thrust and footwork must be unified. Arriving before or after weapon creates openings.
Maintain awareness of entire jo length. Rear end is also a weapon.

thirty-one-jo-kata.name: 31 Jo Kata
thirty-one-jo-kata.description: Foundational jo kata of Iwama Aikido, consisting of 31 movements. Embodies Riai principle - integration of jo, ken, and taijutsu.

opening.title: Opening Sequence
opening.description: Kata begins with choku-tsuki followed by series of strikes and thrusts establishing rhythm.

middle.title: Middle Section
middle.description: Middle section includes more complex combinations including kaeshi-tsuki (returning thrust) and various striking patterns.

closing.title: Closing Sequence
closing.description: Kata concludes with decisive movements demonstrating all principles practiced, ending with proper zanshin.

notes: Learn each movement individually before attempting to flow through entire kata. Quality over speed.
Every movement in kata has martial application. Practice with awareness of imaginary opponents.
31 Jo Kata should be practiced both solo and with 31 Kumijo (paired practice) to fully understand applications.

tachi-dori.name: Sword Taking
tachi-dori.description: Empty-hand sword disarm - Technique using taijutsu to disarm sword from armed opponent.

face.title: Facing Sword
face.description: Opponent attacks with sword. You move to avoid the cut.

control.title: Enter and Control
control.description: Enter danger zone and control opponent's sword arm.

disarm.title: Disarm Sword
disarm.description: Apply locking or throwing technique while simultaneously disarming sword from opponent's hand.

notes: Timing and irimi are critical when facing weapons.
Practice with wooden sword (bokken) for safety.

jo-dori.name: Staff Taking
jo-dori.description: Empty-hand staff disarm - Technique using taijutsu to disarm staff from armed opponent.

face.title: Facing Staff
face.description: Opponent attacks with jo. You move to avoid strike or thrust.

entry.title: Entry
entry.description: Enter inside staff's reach and control opponent.

disarm.title: Disarm Staff
disarm.description: Apply technique to disarm staff or throw opponent.

notes: Jo has long reach, requires decisive entry.
Be careful both ends of staff are weapons.

tanto-dori.name: Knife Taking
tanto-dori.description: Empty-hand knife disarm - Technique using taijutsu to disarm knife from armed opponent. Often uses Gokyo.

face.title: Facing Knife
face.description: Opponent attacks with knife. This is the most dangerous situation.

evade.title: Evade and Control
evade.description: Avoid stab/cut path and immediately control knife-holding arm.

disarm.title: Disarm Knife (Gokyo)
disarm.description: Apply Gokyo or similar technique with reverse grip to safely disarm knife.

notes: In Gokyo, reverse grip keeps knife blade pointing away from you.
Always keep opponent's elbow extended so they cannot cut.
Tanto-dori requires highest concentration and precision.

jo-nage.name: Staff Throw
jo-nage.description: Using staff to throw opponent - Technique using jo as tool to lock and throw opponent whether empty-handed or armed.

hold.title: Hold Jo
hold.description: You are holding jo, opponent attacks you (may be empty-handed or armed).

control.title: Use Jo to Control
control.description: Use jo to block, strike, or lock opponent.

throw.title: Throw with Jo
throw.description: Use jo as lever or control point to throw opponent.

notes: Jo-nage differs from Jo-dori - here YOU are holding the staff.
Jo can be used in many ways: strike, thrust, lock, or as lever.
